docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has blocked a Maine law designed to cut the cost of prescriptions with the threat of price controls, saying that it would probably be ruled unconstitutional. The preliminary injunction granted on Thursday by Judge D. Brock Hornby of Federal District Court, prevents the state from enforcing the law pending the outcome of a lawsuit by the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, which represents drug companies.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Prescription-Drug Law Put on Hold in Maine

docs.abstract: Federal Judge D Brock Hornby issues preliminary injunction preventing Maine from enforcing law designed to cut cost of prescription drugs with threat of price controls (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Philadelphia teachers went on strike at the close of school today for the first time since 1981. The strike followed a breakdown this afternoon in negotiations for a new contract, although Bob Bedard, a spokesman for the 21,000-member Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, said there was still hope that the schoolchildren here in the nation's seventh-largest district, who number more than 210,000, could return to classes on Monday.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Teachers in Philadelphia Strike as Talks Break Off

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush made it sound like the nuttiest clump of policy granola imaginable. ''How many of you own a rooftop photovoltaic system?'' Mr. Bush asked crowds at several campaign rallies this week, ridiculing Vice President Al Gore's proposal to give tax credits to homeowners who install solar panels for electricity. His message was that the vice president's approach to tax cuts was convoluted and, to many voters, irrelevant.

headline.main: Ridiculing Policies With a Familiar Ring

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush has ridiculed Vice Pres Al Gore's proposal to give tax credits to homeowners who install solar panels for electricity, but Bush included essentially same proposal when he outlined his energy policy last month (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three weeks after a shake-up of its top management, Prudential Securities is preparing to stop trading bonds for institutional clients and to lay off a few hundred traders and other employees, people close to the firm said yesterday. Prudential, which has struggled to compete in the bond business with bigger firms, has not been making money at it lately and wants to reduce the volatility of its trading results, the people said. The changes, expected to be announced next week, will not affect the bond sales and trading Prudential does for its individual customers, they said.

headline.main: Prudential Securities to Stop Bond Trading for Institutions

docs.abstract: Prudential Securities is preparing to stop trading bonds for institutional clients and to lay off a few hundred traders and other employees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Bob Franks opened the final act of his race for the Senate today with a bus tour aimed at driving home his message that he has begun to cut into the lead of his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine. As political theater goes, the props were in place but the house was thin. An immense silver bus carried only Mr. Franks and an aide for most of the trip from here in Somerset County to Newark to Pennsauken and then to a television appearance in Philadelphia, and the audiences at the two public events were closer to claques than crowds.

headline.main: In New Jersey, One Senate Candidate Goes on the Road as His Rival Goes on the Air

docs.abstract: Rep Bob Franks stages bus tour aimed at showing he has cut lead of Jon S Corzine in their Senate race in New Jersey; two public events on tour are sparsely attended; Corzine gives press and broadcast interviews and releases two new television commercials attacking Franks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HOOKING UP By Tom Wolfe 293 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25. The reader of the new Tom Wolfe anthology, ''Hooking Up,'' comes away with three impressions: that Mr. Wolfe is a keen observer and stylist, using his magnetic eye for social details and high-caloric prose to energize his reportage; that he employs those same gifts in his fiction, but frequently uses them to stack the deck against his heroes; and that he is even less fair-minded in his essays, substituting gross simplifications, dubious assertions and highly selective case studies for reasoned argument. The reporter as showman too often becomes the social critic as con man.

headline.main: Both a Social Pointillist and a Cultural Partisan

docs.abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews book Hooking Up by Tom Wolfe; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The soft-money deal between the candidates for the United States Senate in New York has backfired, some undecided voters say, drawing more attention to the fund-raising activities of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio than if they had quietly raised and spent millions and not made an issue of it. ''They're both saying, 'I have more integrity; I want to stop this,' '' said Bob Harrison, a high school social studies teacher in Amsterdam, N.Y. ''But neither of them are following through.''

headline.main: Undecided Voters Remain Skeptical On Soft Money Pact in Senate Race

docs.abstract: Some undecided voters say that soft-money deal between candidates for United States Senate in New York has backfired, drawing more attention to fund-raising activities of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A Lazio than if they had quietly raised and spent millions and not made an issue of it; photos (Ninth article in series Undecided: The Soft Money Issue)

docs.lead_paragraph: Labor expenses for businesses showed the smallest gain in a year in the third quarter, government figures showed today, suggesting that the 30-year low unemployment rate was not stoking inflation. The 0.9 percent increase in the employment cost index in the three months ended Sept. 30 came after a 1 percent gain in the second quarter, the Labor Department said. The third-quarter increase was the smallest since a 0.8 percent rise in the third quarter of 1999.

headline.main: Labor Expenses for Businesses Climbed Slightly in September

docs.abstract: Labor Department's employment cost index in three months ended Sept 30 rose 0.9 percent compared with 1 percent in in second quarter, suggesting that 30-year low unemployment rate is not adding to inflation; Commerce Department says record 67.7 percent of households owned their houses in third quarter, compared with 67.2 percent in second quarter; rise in ownership among Hispanic families to 46.7 percent from 45.4 percent led the increase (M)
docs.snippet: Labor expenses for businesses showed the smallest gain in a year in the third quarter, government figures showed today, suggesting that the 30-year low unemployment rate was not stoking inflation.    The 0.9 percent increase in the employment cost...

docs.lead_paragraph: In its waning days, Congress is squandering the burgeoning budget surplus on ill-considered spending projects and tax cuts that will go primarily to those who least need help. The wastage will strip Congress of the money it needs to do anything important for years to come and will deprive the two presidential candidates of the money they need to pay for their proposals. President Clinton promised yesterday to veto the tax bill, but his veto can force fixes of only the bill's worst features. The tax bill does a few things right. It raises the minimum wage by a dollar over two years, provides more money for the low-income housing tax credit and gives teaching hospitals and skilled nursing homes desperately needed relief.
docs.abstract: Editorial scores Congress for squandering burgeoning budget surplus on ill-considered spending projects and tax cuts that will go primarily to those who least need help; says wastage will strip Congress of money it needs to do anything important for years to come and will deprive two presidential candidates of money they need to pay for their proposals; says Congress should rescue $7.8 billion plan to restore Everglades

docs.lead_paragraph: Gary C. Wendt, the chief executive of Conseco Inc., the deeply troubled insurance and finance company, paced slowly in a gray-carpeted conference room at his company's sprawling headquarters here, speaking to 20 of his top executives gathered together for the first time. ''Make no mistake,'' he said. ''You're going to have someone in charge.''

headline.main: Conseco's Turnaround by Fire; Insurer Dodges Foreclosure, but Can't Shake Skepticism

docs.abstract: Many people outside Conseco Inc, deeply troubled insurance and finance company, are skeptical about Conseco chief executive Gary C Wendt's reorganization plans for company; Wendt, former head of GE Capital Services, is trying to engineer recovery for company that has lost around 90 percent of its market value; company's earnings have been declining for several quarters and one-time charges in second quarter contributed to loss of $405 million; graph; photo (M)
